the code to rewrite the cache in the [message] opcode is nearly trivial, just a cut-n-paste from [chatterbox]. One problem is that there are three different places in [message] where this has to happen. So I wanted to make some smart nodes similar to [htmlcode] but capable of returning a list of values. But that requires changes to *.pm files.

So instead just make an [updatechatter] htmlcode (already waiting for you) and call it from three places in [message] and one place in [chatterbox]. My search code is pretty conprehensive so I don't think you'll have any problems using nlgoto (though I have no idea what it was meant to be for).

You could also set the expiration time based on the oldest message in the chatterbox (but with a minimum of 60 or 30) (have [showchatter] squirrel the oldest message's time in %HTMLVARS or something) so things expire closer to how they currently do.

I think it is important to skip all of the caching for people who /ignore. Checking for /ignore is trivial. This will mean you'll have to be careful to not cache public chatter obeying /ignore when a person who is /ignore-ing chats something. (So maybe just invalidating the cache is a good first step.)

Part of the reason this really bothers me is because the chatterbox XML ticker has this same bug and I could see it happen when watching the DB transactions. The cache would expire and one instance would start the query to get the chatter to update the cache, but things were slow enough that it wouldn't finish in time and so 5 other instances would give up waiting and submit the same query and these would clog up the DB. But what doesn't make sense now that I'm thinking about your patch is that this nearly identical query is done (and much more often) by [showchatter] and I don't think I ever saw it clog up the DB...

Okay, I'm supposed to be doing something else but the curiousity killed me. The problem is that the chatterbox XML ticker uses a form of select on tstamp that the MySQL optimizer can't handle. tstamp needs to be factored out to be by itself on one side of the inequality. I can't divert from my real tasks to do that right now, so anyone feel free to make it match the one in [showchatter] (including changing the 600 to 500). This change also needs to be done to the newest nodes XML ticker (to match how [newest nodes] does it now).

Sorry, I was in such shock when I realized how nodelets are and aren't cached that it took a while to digest things. And finally having that mental dissonance about the query being so very slow and yet being run for every single page hit cleared up, I can see that this will be a great idea.

But one way you can reduce the "hurry, everyone update it, it just expired" problem follows. Note that you seem to underestimate this problem. With your current code, when the cache expires, every page hit tries to update the cache until they all notice that it has been done. It gets pretty easy for this to cause dozens of mod_perls to be updating the cache at the same time...

But you can improve this by having the code that checks for expiration to add, say, rand(30) to the timestamp. So make the minimum update interval 30 but with rand(30) added when you check for expiration and we'll be in great shape.

Thanks tons for looking at this, writing that patch, forcing me to think about, not freaking out when I freaked out, and (I hope) doing a few of things I've suggested.

BTW, since I'm updating the wiki, [PodMaster], [Aristotle], [Mr. Muskrat], and [jaybonci] (and probably others) thanks for the patches. It looks like someone besides me applied [PodMaster]'s (we should put [PodMaster] into [pmdev] so [crazyinsomniac] doesn't have to get dusted off for stuff like this) so there are a couple I don't have to feel guilty about anymore. [I kinda hoped to use parselinks/htmlScreen() everywhere instead of escapeHTML() everywhere just so [] still makes links, but that's a minor point]. My real-job project is near the deadline and I'm probably going to miss it, so I've been pretty scarse and haven't found the time to digest and apply patches.

And, of course, a big thanks to [ar0n] and [Petruchio] for lots of things.

[theorbtwo], 2003-02-08
OK, there's an RFC patch showing my basic idea at [id://233651]. The basic idea is that we cache the rendered version of the public chatter for the [chatterbox] nodelet, and invalidate it in the [message] [opcode]. As you can see, the patch is designed to be minimal. It requires no new nodes or changes to the db. There needs to be a small patch to [message], too, but the required changes there are almost trivial, for the first version. For the second version (which will make the race condition noted later harder to hit), there are some larger changes there, but no larger then the this patch. There are a number of problems with it, however.

First off, there's a bit of a race. When the cache becomes invalid (either because somebody talked, or because it's timed out), there's a window between when the chatterbox nodelet is fetched from the DB and when it's written back out with the new cached text, during which if a second request for the chatterbox nodelet comes through, both processes will rewrite the cache, causing two queries against the [messages] dbtable (which is still better then what we're seeing now), and two writes of the cached text back to [message] (we currently don't have any writes). Changing [message] to recreate the cache, rather then mearly invalidating it, will cause this race to happen only when the cached copy times out, rather then being invalidated by a talker, which will make it much less of a problem.

Also, there's the problem of tradeoffs. In my proposed world order, we're rewriting [chatterbox] fairly often, and stuffing more data in it. However, we're not performing nearly as many complex queries aginst [messages], which is a good thing, IMnsHO. (It's not a tremendously complex query, but it's far from simple, and we're doing it for every hit on the chatterbox!)

Hmmpf. I just thought of another problem, and more specificly, another way in which the chatterbox's contents vary from user to user: /ignores. Almost any form of caching of the rendered chatterbox would destroy /ignore. Either we'd have to check if the user is ignoring anybody, and if so, ignore the cache, or we'd have to make /ignore not work against public chatter. Ignoring the cache would mean increased code complexity, and increased web server time. It wouldn't actively hurt the db server's performance, but it would decrese how much we're helping it.

Anyway, next problem: I'm reusing the nlgoto field of the nodelet table. Anybody know what it was for?

This caching scheme doesn't help other consumers of public chatter at all. Fullpage chat and the chatterbox xml ticker would be just as load-heavy as always -- more so, in fact, since they would be less likely to be in the db server's cache.

Anyway, does anybody see problems that I'm missing? Am I missing a way around these problems? Will Rocky fall for Natalia's trap? Do you think it's not worth implementing given all these gotchas? I'm of the oppinion that while this isn't perfect, it's a lot better then what we've got now, and given a little more work, will be amazingly much better then what we've got now. Even if not, this has helped me understand Everything better, and made [tye] notice that we're not using the existing caching mechinisims for most of the nodelets.

The main advantage of caching the rendered chatterbox is that it reduces web server load. We don't have a problem with web server load.

For a cache to be effective, you need to prevent 20 requests all trying to update it at the same time right after it gets invalidated. About the only workable solution I see is a separate cache-managing process (perhaps one per web server). The benefits are not such that I consider that to be my top priority, though I encourage others to work on it. Perhaps coordinate with [perrin] who I think is working on better caching.

[theorbtwo] - Fri Feb 7 6:24 AM EST

Recently, I've been thinking about caching for the rendered form of the chatterbox. Basically, the biggest question I have is if it's acceptable to split public chatter and private chatter into two separate nodelets. It's possible either way, but if we do so, we get to have the caching free -- we can leverage the existing nodelet-caching code, but only if we make the chatterbox static across time and user boundries. Making the chatterbox nodelet cachable as a whole would mean moving private messages elsewhere (another nodelet, most likely), making the hints always-on, and removing the "(hh:mm ago)" part of the time hint (title attribute) on the last publicchatter. I think those are acceptable losses. If people don't want to move the private chatter elsewhere, we can "simply" recreate the caching code, create some place to put the cached HTML (or reuse the currently-unused, if I understand correctly, caching fields for the chatterbox nodelet), and cache only the rendered portion, loosing only the relitive-to-now part of the title of the last entry -- that's the only thing that changes constantly on that part.

Also, we need to change everything that generates public chatter to explicitly invalidate the cache. That's not difficult, I think -- most of it goes through the [message] opcode.

My other question is, of course, why hasn't somebody ([tye], I'm looking at you) already done this?

[JayBonci], 2003-02-03
Added a patch [parselinks - (patch)], to address a security concern with image sources. There is nothing to stop someone from exploiting our open URL API to create trojan image sources using the browser's auto-loading of images to fetch a URL calling priviledged opcodes.

For instance: <img src=/?node_id=12345678&op=nuke>

Sure, it's a broken image, but the browser doesn't know that until it has wiped out a pile of sensitive nodes, or added some malicious user to [gods]. I've submitted a fix for this problem in the patch, which eliminates img items with a src that contains a ?.

The patch assumes that most everything goes through [parselinks] (htmlcode), as it does on E2. The other approach would be to strip them at submit time, but the change would have to be made into all doctext bearing maintenances.

The other side of this vulnerability is retrieving a URL that is a redirect to a local site priviledged opcode, but I am now sure if browsers follow HTTP redirects for images. My guess would be yes. The second stage of this (which I will be patching in ecore1.0, pre.8, e2, etc) are referrer vulnerabilities from offsite links. This is a much lower priority problem, but one I'd like to sit down and address as well. Comments on either security problem are welcome.

I was hoping to post a reply to the latest call for free-for-all access to the PM source.

Also, security by obscurity is no security at all.
I understand the point of that old saw, but it isn't actually true. A great deal of security is obscurity. If I were designing a new system, then I'd certainly open the design to public review rather than keep the design secret. That is quite a bit different than having a live system that has had several security problems found (and fixed) in the last few months.

Opening up free access to the source could certainly increase the rate at which any remaining security problems are found. However, there wouldn't be a team looking specifically for security problems so the ones found would most likely be by people doing the looking for "bad" reasons and so we might not even get the security problems fixed if they are exploited subtley enough.

[mt2k] couldn't have guessed how to munge things without access to the source. I'll take a layer of obscurity until such time as a good security review of the site has been completed.

The other problem is wasted time. If we start getting patches from random yahoos who think they have are helping but don't have a solid clue, then we just make the resource problem worse. I've personally lobbied and gotten two [gods] added specifically to help get the good patches that [pmdev|you guys] have already provided but [gods|us deadbeats] haven't applied. One had "real life" get in the way for several months and the other switched to working on site documentation so there are still probably half-a-dozen patches that should be applied but haven't been.

So I think the best plan for "getting help" is to continue to add people who meet the requirements of 1) trust and 2) competence to [pmdev] if they show an interest in contributing. The addition of [gods] is a much more serious matter but I think it has been long enough that it might be time to consider the next candidate there...

If random people want to tackle what I consider the #1 problem, the node cache, then they can download 0.8 as I don't think there are any PM-specific changes to that part of the code.

(For months this wasn't happening but, once again...) The most common reason for an error is DB server overload which can generate dozens (perhaps hundreds) of errors. The worst thing to do in such a situation is to add to the DB server load by writing records of the errors to a table.

What would be useful would be to separate the current /tmp/everything.errlog into two streams, a trace log and an error log. The current printLog() should be for trace log entries. But the error reporting mechanism should only write one record to the trace log and put any extra details (like the code in question and the call stack -- both of which are rarely useful at this point, unfortunately) into the error log. Even if we eliminate the usually-useless details, a separate error log is useful.

The trace log sometimes contains sensitive information and so shouldn't be made available to [pmdev]. The error log might as well, but there is a solution for that: provide a pmdevsuperdoc page where you can enter an error number and get back the details on the error (by searching backward in the error log). It would only work if done via the web server where the error happened. A link to get to the other server would be nice on such a page.
